Wondering how to get started? Here are a few tips:

1. Invite your players

Invite them with either their email address or their Obsidian Portal username.

2. Edit your home page

Make a few changes to the home page and give people an idea of what your campaign is about. That will let people know you’re serious and not just playing with the system.

3. Choose a theme

If you want to set a specific mood for your campaign, we have several backgrounds to choose from. Accentuate it by creating a top banner image.

4. Create some NPCs

Characters form the core of every campaign, so take a few minutes to list out the major NPCs in your campaign.

A quick tip: The “+” icon in the top right of every section is how to add a new item, whether it’s a new character or adventure log post, or anything else.

5. Write your first Adventure Log post

The adventure log is where you list the sessions and adventures your party has been on, but for now, we suggest doing a very light “story so far” post. Just give a brief overview of what the party has done up to this point. After each future session, create a new post detailing that night’s adventures.

One final tip: Don’t stress about making your Obsidian Portal campaign look perfect. Instead, just make it work for you and your group. If everyone is having fun, then you’re using Obsidian Portal exactly as it was designed, even if your adventure log isn’t always up to date or your characters don’t all have portrait pictures.

That’s it! The rest is up to your and your players.

page.title: Chase Scene
page.content: h3. Hook: The heroes witness an assassin shoot down an important dignitary on the streets of Market Town. The assassin discards his crossbow and darts into a crowded market, where he is difficult to spot, but his rough, shabby appearance makes it difficult for him to hide completely. The heroes are the only ones who have seen the assassin. NPCs are tending to the dignitary. Can the heroes catch the assassin before he disappears? h3. The Chase: During the chase, measure the distance from the assassin to the heroes in spaces, each one representing an arbitrary distance. You can use a marked diagram if you’d like to give the heroes a visual aid. In general, any action the heroes take to speed themselves up should move them one space closer to the assassin. Any action the heroes take to slow the assassin should move all of the heroes one space closer (representing the assassin losing ground) except the hero who took the action (who probably had to stop running to take the action). Modify this as you see fit based on the action. Explain to the players that they are maintaining a steady pace, not running all out, but pacing themselves and avoiding the hazards of the city around them. The chase itself plays out in a series of rounds during which each hero will have the opportunity to take an action or react to the environment. During the chase, the assassin will lead them through several different neighbourhoods and districts. Ultimately, the assassin is trying to reach the Scumm and Villainy Bar in Crimetown. The owner is a friend of his and maintains a secret back room the assassin can vanish into. The owner will cover for him. The heroes begin the space five spaces behind the assassin. If, at any point, none of the heroes is within seven spaces of the assassin, the assassin ducks into an alley and disappears, escaping. h3. The Rooftops: During the chase, one or more of the heroes can try to gain the rooftops to make the chase easier. This option is called out twice during the chase, but players should be able to do so at any time. During the round in which the player climbs up to the rooftops, they lose a space. Thereafter, they must attempt a skill check each round to navigate the rooftops. If they fail, they fall to the streets, lose a space, and take falling damage. If they succeed, they gain a space. Heroes on the rooftops may jump down at any time with a skill check. If they succeed, they continue the chase. If they fail, they take falling damage and lose a space. h3. Round 1: The Market The assassin barrels through a crowded market which makes it slow going for both himself and the heroes. Allow the players to take an action to mitigate the crowd. Also, call attention to the bunting and streamers hanging down from the low rooftops and market stalls to suggest the idea of climbing onto the rooftops. If a hero does something to mitigate or disperse the crowd, allow that hero (or all the heroes based on the action) to gain a space. If a hero attempts to predict the assassin’s route, allow them to make a skill check as described in the next round. h3. Round 2: The Market The assassin continues to make his way through the thick crowd. Continue as you did in the previous round, but don’t call further attention to the rooftops. However, ask everyone to make a skill check to check their knowledge of the city. The check should be difficult. If the check succeeds, tell the player that the assassin’s rough clothing and demeanour would make it difficult for him to vanish here in Market Town. He may be running for the bridge to Crime Town, a slum neighbourhood across the river, where he may be able to go to ground. Warn them, however, that the information is just a guess and could be wrong. If any of the PCs ask, they can navigate a shortcut through the city. Ask them to make a skill check as they cut into an alley, but warn them that, if they fail to navigate, they will end up lost and be out of the chase. h3. Round 3: The Side Street The assassin bursts out of the market and into a straight side street. The street is not very crowded and provides a nice straight run with no outlets and it offers a clear line of sight. After a moment, also suggest that this might be a good place to sprint all out, but warn the heroes they might push too hard and fatigue themselves, losing some ground. Allow any heroes who want to to make a skill check to sprint. Move them up a space if they succeed. They lose a space and fall back a bit if they fail. Also, allow any other actions to slow down the assassin you feel might be appropriate in the situation. h3. Round 4: The Horse Street The assassin turns a corner and darts down a street filled with carts, labourers, and draft animals. He takes out a long dagger and slashes at the flank of a horse as he darts past. The terrified animal whinnies and tears itself free of its harness, bolting up the street right toward the heroes, knocking people aside and injuring them as it charges out of control. Allow the heroes a chance to react to the horse. If they seem intent on ignoring the horse, remind them it is charging right toward them and may run wild through the streets, injuring many people before it is caught and calmed down. If no one reacts, ask each hero to make a save. If they fail, they lose a space. If one of the heroes attempts to calm or capture the horse, he can prevent the rest of the heroes from having to make saves if successful. If someone ends up on a horse somehow and takes control of it (which should be a difficult maneuver), allow them to gain a space. Thereafter, they gain two spaces every round until the heroes reach the Crimetown Alleys, whereupon the horse will not enter the narrow streets and will have to be abandoned. h3. Round 5: The Winding Street If there is a hero navigating the back alleys, ask for a second skill check as they attempt to find the shortcut to the bridge. Meanwhile, the assassin darts down a winding, curved street, crowded with citizens. Describe the street and the chase, but the winding road doesn’t allow clean lines of sight or let the heroes sprint. In all likelihood, the heroes will not be able to do much here. h3. Round 6: The Crimetown Bridge The bridge to Crimetown crosses a wide, slow-moving river. It is not terribly crowded, but there are a few people milling about on the bridge and numerous market stalls. If the hero navigating the shortcut succeeded on both skill checks, he bursts onto the bridge ahead of the assassin and can attempt to tackle him. This should be a moderate check. If it fails, allow him to pick up the chase one space behind the assassin. Now, the assassin slashes at a passerby on the bridge and shoves him over the railing. The citizen begins flailing into the water, bleeding freely. He is in imminent danger of drowning or bleeding to death. The other people on the bridge look shocked and alarmed, but no one is jumping into help him. If there are any heroes on the rooftops, they will have to jump down as the river is too wide to continue their path. A hero might attempt to jump directly into the river to save the drowning man. Meanwhile, heroes on the bridge can sprint after assassin, gaining ground as they could in the Side Street. If someone leaps into the river to rescue the citizen, allow them to do so with an easy check, but they can’t rejoin the race as the rescue takes too long. h3. Round 7: The Crimetown Streets The assassin enters the rundown, dirty streets of Crimetown. At this point, if no one is within three spaces of the assassin, he darts into a side alley and disappears. Allow the closest hero a difficult skill check to spot his hiding place to continue the chase. If the hero spots him, he will realize it and bolt again, but the delay was enough to let every hero gain a space. If the heroes try to bluff or stalk the hidden assassin, he will remain hidden for a few minutes and then slowly make his way to the Scumm and Villainy Bar and Grill. The heroes should be able to ambush him with a skill check or two. If the assassin doesn’t attempt to hide, heroes may take advantage of the straight run to sprint as before or attempt other actions to slow down the assassin. A hero might also try to get back onto the rooftops. h3. Round 8: The Crime Town Streets The long, run-down street continues and the assassin continues running. Allow heroes to sprint or take other actions. In addition, draw attention to the sagging drain pipes, low eaves, and clothes hanging lines to remind the heroes about climbing on to the rooftops again. h3. Round 9: The Back Alleys The assassin darts into the tight back alleys of Crime Town. A horse will not ride into these narrow alleys beneath low overhangs. If no hero is within two spaces of the assassin or on the rooftops within four spaces of the assassin, the assassin disappears. Allow the closest hero a difficult skill check to spot his hiding place (as on the Crime Town Streets). Otherwise, the assassin gets away. Otherwise, few actions are possible here, but allow creative heroes a chance to close the distance. h3. Round 10: The Crime Town Market The assassin emerges from the alleys into a crowded market filled with dirty, grubby tents and poor merchants, citizens, and criminals. The crowd impedes both the assassin and the heroes. Allow the heroes a chance to mitigate the crowd and catch up, gaining a space. h3. End: The Scumm and Villainy Bar and Grill The assassin ducks into the Scumm and Villainy Bar and Grill. Any hero within two spaces knows where the assassin went. However, the assassin disappears into a secret room immediately after entering and the owner covers for him. The heroes will have to ransack the place or question the owner and may end up in a [[Bar Fight | fight]], but that’s a different encounter.

page.title: Bar Fight
page.content:
h3. Hook
h4. Coming from [[Chase Scene]]
The PCs burst into the Scumm and Villainy Tavern in Crimetown, only to find the assassin disappeared into thin air. Raucous laughter fills the air, which is thick with the stench of too many people in too small an area for too long. A large human, clearly drunk, roughly grabs the serving wench and demands more ale for his table, which is already littered with empty bottles. A Human Guard lounges by the door, eyeing the PCs as they enter. An armoured Dragonborn Soldier nurses an ale at the bar, two seats empty on either side of him, his shield resting against his chair. The innkeeper looks at the adventurers and says, "What're you lot here for?" Can the PCs locate the assassin?
h3. NPCs
If the PCs draw their weapons, the NPCs do as well. If the PCs fight with their fists, so do the NPCs, at least until the innkeeper tosses the berserker his Greataxe (when the berserker is bloodied).
h4. Innkeeper
The Innkeeper won't give up the assassin's location easily, and knows the PCs are looking for him. A bribe
h4. Human Guard
He eyes the PCs weapons and armour, hoping he can relieve them of some of their money. If a fight breaks out, he'll eagerly jump in to help the berserker. He will also draw his weapon when the berserker does.
h4. Human Berserker
Will initiate the fight if the PCs insult him or bother the innkeeper for too long. Draws his weapon when bloodied, causing the rest of the NPCs to do so as well.
h4. Human Rabble
The rabble at the berserkers table join the fight by using the bottles as improvised weapons, both smashing them into the PCs and hurling them in their direction.
h4. Dragonborn Soldier
The dragonborn soldier perks up when the fight occurs, eager to prove his strength. He honours the PCs decision to fight with arms or not, and only draws his weapon when the PCs do.

page.title: The Isle of Mists
page.content:
The Isle of Mists is a small island off the coast of [[Drakon | Drakon]] and is inhabited by Slavers and roaming [[Monsters | monsters]]. The whole island is surrounded by reefs and a thick foggy mist that obscures vision making it near impossible to sail in and out of without some [[Magic Compass | form of aid]].
The island is roughly 100 miles in length and 50 miles wide, with a few bays and inlets along the coastline. There are four major cities on the island, connected by a main road running the length of the island. All of the cities are controlled by Slavers and their main purposes are to support the slave trading network that is the backbone of the island's economy.

page.title: Silverfield
page.content:
h2. About
Silverfield is a city on [[The Isle of Mists | The Isle of Mists]]. Silverfield controls both the largest available farmland on the island as well as [[Silverfield Mine| Silverfield Mine]] (which was first used to mine silver, has since expanded into multiple ores) for which it is named. It takes in tons of raw materials each day, but doesn't process them itself; most are shipped north to Drummond's Point.
h3. Politics
The city is governed by a council of merchant families: Sadett, Tanah, Risol, Noto, and Zuhrukt. These families play off each other for control of the city, all attempting to maximize their family's profits from the island. Many slaves and goods are shipped off the island for sale in Drakon and Zhestok.
h3. Demographics
Silverfield is divided into 4 districts: Slave, Warehouse, Tavern, and Market.
h4. Slave District
The slave district is almost purely slave quarters, mashed together to form a densely populated area. There are no services available here, so sewage lays in the street with the garbage, creating a most awful stench. Houses are made from mud, clay, and thatch, with exceptionally few having any wood in their construction. There is a slave market along the main road, where everything is for sale; food, trinkets, services, and themselves.
h4. Warehouse District
This is where all the raw materials are stored on their way to the other cities. Warehouses are heavily guarded, and tend to be built right into the walls of the city. Each is owned by a merchant family, with their crests featured prominently on the front of the building, and on the guards' livery. Even the crates inside the warehouses are stamped with the crest.
h4. Tavern District
The tavern district is filled with tavern, brothels, and living places for the guards of the city. Since the guards have little else to occupy their time when they are off shift, there are a multitude of taverns here. They are usually filled to the brim from sundown to daybreak, guards usually nursing hangovers throughout the day. During the day they have night-shift guards to take care of, but the district is largely quiet during the day with most of the guards working.
h4. Market District
This is where passing merchants sell their wares, guards buy new weapons and armour with the money they earned gambling last night, and some slave trading happens. Most slave trade happens at [[Drummond's Point]], but some does happen here. Noble families also do large amounts of raw material purchasing here, to feed their processing facilities at Drummond's Point.
h3. Liberation
Silverfield has been successfully liberated from the slave traders thanks to the initial infiltration by [[Party | The Party]]. It is now under the control of the former slaves with its main defensive walls well intact. A large majority of the interior wooden buildings have been burned down due to the large fire that broke out during the liberation battle. However, the main armory is intact along with a large cache of weapons and armour.

page.title: The Grey Keep
page.content:
An ancient elven keep shrouded in fog on the cliffs of the Isle of Mists. The keep is the ancestral home of the [[Lord of the Mists]], a powerful mysterious figure. The Keep is of dwarven construction, unlike the ruined elven tree city, and features thick, high walls with secret passages throughout the building.
Spectres of the souls of dead elves run the Keep, allowing the Lord to have minimal staff. They appear to be the souls of the elven children who would serve the Lord when the Isle was under elven control. Humans are not welcome in the Grey Keep and will be hunted down by the spectres if they are detected inside the keep. A powerful ward exists to cause great unease in humans approaching, with only the most stalwart warriors able to touch the doors.

The swamplands is an area located near the center of the Isle of Mists, situated between the cities of [[Silverfield | Silverfield]] and [[Haverton | Haverton]]. The main road runs along the east edge of the swamplands, with mainly forest surrounding the rest.

page.title: Ruins of Elven City
page.content:
An old Elven city situated near the center of the [[Swamplands | swamplands]]. Now in ruins, it was once a great city full of Elfs who lived in peace before the monsters and slavers came to the island. The city consts of many large and tall trees, where buildings have been build high up in the treetops. The city is quite noticeable from a distance in the swamp due to it containing the only large trees in the surrounding area.
The Elven City was also the home of the [[Great Master | Great Master]] who had sworn to protect the lands of the [[The Isle of Mists | Isle of Mists]] from any danger. After [[Party | the Party]] travels through the Elven city, they explore the ruins and find the chamber of the Great Master, long since dead at the top of the tallest tower.
Varis assumes the duties of the Great Master after taking the Magic Wooden Shield, Magic Longbow and Eyes of the Eagle mask from the chamber.

page.title: Silverfield Mine
page.content:
The Silverfield Mine is a silver mine a short ride outside of [[Silverfield]] on [[The Isle of Mists | The Isle of Mists]].
It is an old mine, with the elves who used to reside on the island using it for their silver production. The current owners, human slave traffickers, have expanded its tunnels to reach gemstones, iron, and other useful minerals. The workforce is mostly composed of dwarves, prized by the slavers for their mining expertise and hardy constitutions underground.
Used caverns have been converted into refineries, smithies, slave quarters, and storage. A mining cart system with rail cars and elevators is used to transport goods from the bottom of the mines to the surface. Typically, wagon trains filled with output from the mine leave twice per day, once in the morning and once in the evening.
Human guards aren't present in the mines beyond the entrance, allowing the dwarves to govern themselves. A foreman is given authority to run the mine as he pleases, along with a cadre of armed dwarven guards, topside privileges, and rather opulent living quarters.

page.title: Eversail
page.content:
Eversail is a large port city on the continent of [[Drakon]]. Most trade and shipping routes to and from [[Zhestok]] come through Eversail before continuing to their destination.
The first human explorers settled Eversail because of its natural harbour, which provides shelter from storms and high winds. The Harbour Island provides an adequate storm break, and is an ideal location for its lighthouse.
h4. Government
The Guild Council is the ruling authority in Eversail. Each of the five guilds has a permanent seat on the council, along with the high priest from the Church of Isten and from the Temple of Anya. The council appoints one of their members to be Head of Council, who in turn appoints an advisor to also sit on the council. This seat is highly contended for in the city, with much gold being spent on bribes and favours for council members seen as favourites for the Head position. New Heads tend to appoint members of the major Human houses, since the houses are very free with their coin.
h4. Climate
Temperate, wet, low temperature variance between seasons. Alright for farming, excellent fishing stocks.
h4. Economy
Trading centre of Zemia, all trade routes from Dhemet and Khoret come through the city. Overland routes to the north and over the mountains to South Harbour also exist.
Almost any item from anywhere can be found in Eversail, but this is not the place to come for good prices. Cost of living is high, outside of the slums and shanty town, and the markets are opulent. Expect to find excellent bargainers who have been plying their trade for years.
h4. Demographics
Eversail has long been the most populous city on the continent, with almost 50,000 residents (including the shanty town).
Eversail is one of the most diverse cities on Drakon, with only 60% of the walled city's population being pure Human. If the shanty town outside the walls is included, that number shrinks to 30%.
The first settlers were welcomed with open arms by the indigenous population, and much of the Half Elven population lives in Eversail. Where in other cities Half Elves are shunned by both Humans and Elves, here they are often found in positions of influence.

page.title: The Forgotten Isle
page.content: The Forgotten Isle, known to the elves as Isla Zabrav, is the place where it is legended that the gods took their first steps upon [[Zemia]].
The Forgotten Isle, known to the elves as Isla Zabrav, is the place where it is legended that the gods took their first steps upon Zemia.

The Forgotten Isle, known to the elves as Isla Zabrav, is where the gods took their first steps upon [[Zemia]].
h4. History
When [[:isten | Isten]] and [[:anya | Anya]] finally finished constructing Zemia's continents, they took physical form and came down to examine their creation. They stood on the high mountains overlooking the sea and decided that all was good. They sat a while to determine their next course of action, and agreed to create together a series of creatures to enjoy their world. Thus were created the giant races.
Isten created the hill, frost, and fire giants, while Anya created the stone, cloud, and storm giants. Isten looked upon Anya's creations and felt jealous toward them. While he was proud of the brute strength of his frost giants and the fire giants were masterful smiths and warriors, the beauty of the structures created by the stone and cloud giants awed him. He wished he could create such beauty, and struck against them with his giants to destroy the wondrous cloud city hanging before him.
Anya recoiled in horror at Isten's destruction, and created the metallic dragons (her favourite form) in retaliation. The dragons were sent against the giants of Isten to cover for her giants' escape. She took her stone and cloud giants and hid them in the mountains of [[Drakon]], giving them instructions to stay hidden from the world. The storm giants were all but destroyed in the fighting, with just three surviving. Anya gave the remaining three the ability to see omens and portents of the future, in order to protect against any further betrayal by Isten. They took up residence on the three peaks of Isla Zabrav.
Isten took his own giants to [[Zhestok]], and spread them out across the continent. The fire giants went to the mountains, the frost giants to the arctic in the north, and the hill giants went to the hills. To cover his retreat, he made his own dragons. The chromatic dragons
h4. Environment
Isla Zabrav is mountainous, with peaks that rise above the clouds and jungles that choke out the sun. Once off the beaches, the humid air stinks of decaying plant matter as the jungle digests the creatures unlucky or unwary enough to have fallen prey to the massive beasts that roam it. Permanent lenticular clouds surround the three massive snowy summits, but a dauntless hero who braves the icy slopes will feel the sun again at the pinnacle of the mountain. The centre peak is the tallest of the three, and has a permanent storm surrounding it. Recent reports from those souls fortunate enough to have escaped the island say that a scowling visage can be seen in the clouds.
h4. Monsters
Dinosaurs roam this place, giant lizard creatures that time has forgotten. Some are aggressive, others are docile, but their size makes them dangerous to the intrepid adventurer. All manner of beasts and aberrations are found here, but inflated in size.
Storm Giant Quintessent - The perpetual storm at the summit of the central mountain is in fact a storm giant quintessent, one of the three remaining storm giants. She was given the gift of foresight by Anya, but was driven mad by her death/imprisonment.
Storm Giants - on the other two peaks also live storm giants, the remaining two that still live. They are at odds with each other, one believing the portents and omens point to Anya's return, and the other interpreting them in the opposite direction. They both wish the quintessent would calm herself to give them guidance, but gave up trying to help her themselves decades ago.

Anya is the older brother of [[:isten | Isten]]. She watches over him and is teaching him how to create worlds. They have created several worlds together, forming them from dust and populating them with life. She favours gentle worlds, where the races are given freedom to create art in all its forms.
Anya was trapped inside the earth during the [[Dwarven Civil War]], buried beneath the southern mountain. Material God Name supresses her power while she is buried, and she can only give power to a select few. Her worship has fallen out of favour, as the [[Priests of Anya]] could no longer prove her power to their congregations. Her inprisonment has caused the southern mountain to erupt continually, lava flowing down its southern face and rushing towards the sea. The city of [[Hellforge]] was built adjacent to the lava flow, and uses the flow's heat and minerals to run their wondrous forges.
Anya takes the form of a great red dragon, can breath fire, and can fly.

character.title: Isten
character.content:
Isten is the younger brother of [[:anya | Anya]]. Together they have created many worlds, with [[Zemia]] being the most recent. Unlike his sister, Isten favours progress, knowledge, and innovation, desiring the races to use the world they have been given to create new things. He despises art, thinking it purposeless, and has tried in the past to provoke ambition in the races on their worlds. Anya has always found his desires tasteless, believing that a world without poetry a bland world indeed. Since she was older and more powerful, she has always undone his touch upon the worlds, frustrating his attempts at creation.
Isten chafed under his sister's command, desiring to prove that a world of his creation would be just as successful as Anya's worlds. On Zemia, Isten laid the seeds of ambition deep within the dwarves and gnomes, allowing them to corrupt the easily manipulated humans. He planned to use the dwarves to take over the world and remake it the way he saw fit. The ambitious factions within the dwarves caused a rift among the clans, creating a civil war. The innovative gnomes paired with the ambitious dwarven clans to create terrible war machines that swung the war in their favour. When Anya manifested herself on the world to stop the war, Isten sprung his trap, burying her beneath a mountain. He kept her trapped there, suppressing her powers - weakened since she was physically manifested - and allowed his dwarves to win the war.

The innovative gnomes paired with the ambitious dwarven clans to create terrible war machines that swung the war in their favour. When Anya manifested herself on the world to stop the war, Isten sprung his trap, burying her beneath a mountain. He kept her trapped there, suppressing her powers – weakened since she was physically manifested – and allowed his dwarves to win the war.

character.title: Aerandir
character.content:
Hailing from a monastery dedicated to Anya located in the elven city of Cormanthyr on the Isle of Mist, Aerandir was not actually a fully fledged monk when the city was attacked by monsters. He was simply a devout follower of Anya hoping to join the monastery after turning away from a life of wealth accumulated through the sale of medicines and potions. A life that left him spiritually unfulfilled.
Just mere months before the city's destruction Aerandir was finally assigned to a master. Quelenna was an elf female who was known for her wit and cunningness, but Aerandir was not happy to be assigned to her in particular. He had heard that she was strict and harsh in her training methods. Aerandir had only just been taught the most basic forms and movements of martial arts that all higher forms are built upon when the city was attacked.
In the ensuing chaos of the monster attack on the city, Aerandir grabbed what knowledge scrolls he could from his room and the now upended library before rushing out into the city to find his master and help her defend their home. In a brave, but fool-hardy charge against a massive creature, Aerandir was clubbed unconscious from one massive blow to the head and knocked out of the treetop paths to the forest floor below, buried beneath brush and twigs.
When he awoke, in a muddy pile of branches, the world around him was quiet and the smell of ash hung in the air. Where was he? Why did his head hurt?
Whether from the blow to the head or the trauma of losing his home, Aerandir's memory remained patchy at best.

character.content:

The Zuhrukt clan hails from Khoret on the coast of Drakon.
Their crest is a scorpion on a diagonal field of rose pink and brown.

The Zuhrukt clan is the only noble family to incorporate non-humans into the family. They employ non-humans, and have elven blood in some of the younger clan members. They encourage close membership within the clan, and have afforded familial membership to non blood relatives. They have earned exceptional loyalty from their non-human members by ensuring their familial status is passed to their children in the case of their death.
The Zuhrukts have a major focus on trade, and were the first human explorers of Drakon. They ended up settling in the largely uninhabited eastern deserts, where they found large amounts of gold deposits. Unlike the other families, they handsomely rewarded service in their mines instead of forced dwarven labour. This resulted in Khoret being a very multi-cultural city, with non-humans in positions of power.
Their primary goal is to be as rich and opulent as possible, with rank in the Zuhrukt clan displayed by the amount of golden jewelry and fine clothing worn. Zoho, the rotund clan leader, has a ship entirely coated in gold that can be seen for miles without a spyglass in sunny weather.

A young and idealistic paladin who is unusual in the sense that he has been granted powers by Anya, despite being a member of the human race who was responsible for the decline of the followers of Anya. The party encountered Evendur and recruited him into their party during the events of the [[Silverfield | Silverfield]] rebellion. He was discovered in the bowels of the temple of Isten in Silverfield. It was apparent that he had been tortured for his heresy, his belief in Anya in human lands.
h2. Backstory
Evendur was raised in a noble family, as the eldest son, in the city of Lastport. Growing up Evendur had an easy life, as most noble children do. His parents looked at him as the heir of the family, being the eldest son of six, and also because of his apparent natural abilities. While Evendur enjoyed the normal joys of a well-to-do boyhood, like getting to mischief with his peers, he took his parents belief in him to heart and worked and studied hard under Theren, who he admired immensely.
